Ref Table(s).0: WELL_LOG WELLWELL_LOG_TRIPWELL_LOG_PASSWELL_LOG_CURVEWELL_LOG_CURVE_FRAME

Column Comment.0: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for this row.
Column Comment.1: CURVE IDENTIFIER: Unique identification number assigned to the curve or trace.
Column Comment.2: ACQUIRED FOR BUSINESS ASSOCIATE ID: Unique identifier for the businessassociate who ordered the acquisition of the well log. Usually the operator of the well.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: API LOG CODE SYSTEM: A system devised by the American Petroleum Institudepublished in API bulletin D9 (1973)and D9a (1981) used to classify curves. Oftenfound on historic logs, but rarely used in current operations.
Column Comment.5: API LOG CODE SYSTEM: A system devised by the American Petroleum Institudepublished in API bulletin D9 (1973)and D9a (1981) used to classify curves. Oftenfound on historic logs, but rarely used in current operations.
Column Comment.6: API LOG CODE SYSTEM: A system devised by the American Petroleum Institudepublished in API bulletin D9 (1973)and D9a (1981) used to classify curves. Oftenfound on historic logs, but rarely used in current operations.
Column Comment.7: API LOG CODE SYSTEM: A system devised by the American Petroleum Institudepublished in API bulletin D9 (1973)and D9a (1981) used to classify curves. Oftenfound on historic logs, but rarely used in current operations.
Column Comment.8: API LOG CODE SYSTEM: A system devised by the American Petroleum Institudepublished in API bulletin D9 (1973)and D9a (1981) used to classify curves. Oftenfound on historic logs, but rarely used in current operations.
Column Comment.9: BASE CURVE INDICATOR: a Y/N flag that indicates when a curve is a base curve.These curves, generated during a particular logging pass, are used as a depthbenchmark for all other curves.
Column Comment.10: BYPASS INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this well log was acquired during abypass operation.
Column Comment.11: CASED HOLE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this log was acquired in acased hole environment.
Column Comment.12: COMPOSITE INDICATOR: a Y/N flag indicating that this curve is a composite ofcurves taken during multiple passes or combined through other types of processing.
Column Comment.13: CURVE OUOM: Identifies the original unit of measure associated with the log curve.For example, resistivity curves are measured in ohms/meters
Column Comment.14: CURVE OUTPUT TYPE: The format that a parameter is to be output as whenreporting or recreating a digital file, such as integer, floating, double precision etc.
Column Comment.15: CURVE QUALITY: the overall quality of the log curve, such as good, verificationpassed, poor etc.
Column Comment.16: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format colums, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.17: WELL LOG DICTIONARY: The dictionary contains a set of curve names, propertynames and parameters that are used by a well logging contracter during a specifiedperiod of time. At any given time, a contractor may have one or more dictionaries inuse.
Column Comment.18: DICTIONARY CURVE IDENTIFIER; unique identifier for a curve that is shown in adictionary; provides a standard list of curve names.
Column Comment.19: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.20: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.21: EXPLICIT INDEX INDICATOR: A Y/N flag for which Y means that the index isincluded with the curve, N means the index is implicit and must be calculated orcollected from an index curve.
Column Comment.22: FIRST GOOD VALUE: the first good value recorded on the curve.
Column Comment.23: FIRST GOOD VALUE INDEX: the index at which the first good value was recordedon the curve.
Column Comment.24: INDEX IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the occurrance of the well log index orframe.
Column Comment.25: GOOD VALUE TYPE: A list of valid types of good values that are used to indicate thetop and base of useful data gathered during logging operations.
Column Comment.26: INDEX CURVE IDENTIFIER: Use this column to identify the curve that contains theindex values for this curve, used when the index is implicit. If the index is explicit, theindex values are included with the curve (the curve consists of Index - value pairs). Ifthe index is implicit, the index values must be calculated with the interval informationin the header as the curve only contains the values.
Column Comment.28: INDEX UNIT OF MEASURE: the unit of measure nominally used for the well logcurve.
Column Comment.29: JOB IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier assigned to the wireline log job.
Column Comment.30: LAST GOOD VALUE: the last good value recorded during logging.
Column Comment.31: LAST GOOD VALUE INDEX: the index at which the last good value was recorded onthe curve.
Column Comment.32: LOG TOOL PASS NUMBER: the pass number assigned to the well logging pass.
Column Comment.33: LOG TOOLTYPE: A unique identifier for the type of logging tool.
Column Comment.34: MAX INDEX: the maximum index at which values were measured for the curve, Inmany cases the index will be the last measured depth; could also be time.
Column Comment.35: MAXIMUM VALUE: the value of the maximum reading on this curve.
Column Comment.36: MAXIMUM VALUE INDEX The index of the maximum value in the curve.
Column Comment.37: MEAN VALUE: the mean average of the values on the curve.
Column Comment.38: MEAN VALUE STANDARD DEVIATION: The standard deviation of the mean value.
Column Comment.39: MIN INDEX: the minimum index at which values were measured for the curve, Inmany cases the index will be the first measured depth; could also be time.
Column Comment.40: MINIMUM VALUE: the value of the minimum reading on this curve.
Column Comment.41: MINIMUM VALUE INDEX : the index of the minimum value on the curve.
Column Comment.42: MULTIPLE INDEXES INDICATOR: a Y/N flag indicating that this curve containsmultiply indexed values. In this case, each index is stored in an axis (WELL LOGCURVE AXIS)
Column Comment.43: MEASURED WHILE DRILLING INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this log wasacquired during active drilling operations. Acquired while the bit was in the hole.Could be logged while drilling (LWD) or measured while drilling (MWD).
Column Comment.44: NULL COUNT: The number of nulls found on this curve.
Column Comment.45: NULL VALUE REPRESENTATION: the value in the curve that is used to representNULL readings on the curve.
Column Comment.46: ORDER SEQUENCE NUMBER: Indicates the order in which curves are included ona frame.
Column Comment.47: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.48: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this curve is preferred for use.
Column Comment.49: LOG INDEX TYPE: The type of measurement index for the log, such as measureddepth or time. In this case, the index as reported on the log curve header. Use thiscolumn in the case where the WELL LOG CURVE INDEX table is not used. In thiscase, the primary index is the index used in the well curve digit information.
Column Comment.50: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.51: REPORTED DESCRIPTION: Store the narrative text or comments that come in withthe original curve in this column.
Column Comment.52: REPORTED MNEMONIC: the log curve mnemonic as reported in the log curve data;this value is unvalidated and reported as is. Validated version of the curve is foundthrough the CURVE ID.
Column Comment.53: REPORTED UNIT MNEMONIC: The reported units that the curve was captured in.
Column Comment.54: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.55: TRIP OBSERVATION NUMBER: a unique number assigned to the data related to awell log trip. If unique run numbers exist, they may be used if desired. If not, asurrogate component is created.
Column Comment.56: VALUE COUNT: the total number of values found on the well log curve includingNULL values. the count of NULL values is stored in NULL_COUNT. Use the valuecount to calculate the sample spacing as (BASE MD - TOP MD) / (VALUE COUNT -1).
Column Comment.57: WELL LOG IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the well log.
Column Comment.58: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.59: WELL LOG SOURCE: the source of the well log that has been referenced.
Column Comment.60: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.61: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.62: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.63: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.64: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.65: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.66: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
